channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: China’s Xi Jinping Remakes the Communist Party’s History in His Image
item.description: Leaders at an elite meeting enshrined Mr. Xi among the party’s historical giants, paving the way for him to claim a third five-year term.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Communist Party officials are expected to decide this week whether Xi Jinping, left, will be placed among the country’s era-defining leaders.

item.title: Live Updates: Belarus and Poland Trade Threats as Migrant Plight Worsens
item.description: Thousands are camped at the border as dangerous cold sets in. Western officials say Belarus’s leader, who hinted at disrupting gas supplies to Europe, orchestrated the crisis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times

item.title: Poland Gets Support From Europe on Tough Borders
item.description: Faced with the weaponization of migrants from Belarus, the European Union is defending Poland’s hard line even as it withholds funds over rule of law violations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: F.W. de Klerk, Last President of Apartheid South Africa, Dies at 85
item.description: A prominent Afrikaner, he defended the separation of the races before helping to dismantle that system, leading to his sharing the Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela.
item.dc:creator: Marc Lacey
item.media:description: F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela in 1994. They shared the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the end of the apartheid state.

item.title: Palestinian Diplomats Targeted by Israeli Spyware, Official Says
item.description: The accusation, which has not been independently verified, raises new questions over whether Israel is using software made by NSO Group to spy on Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building at an address listed for NSO Group in Herzliya, Israel.

item.title: Sudan’s Top General Entrenches Military Coup, Frustrating Western Efforts
item.description: A little over two weeks after seizing power, Sudan’s top general created a new ruling body led by himself. The civilian prime minister remains under house arrest.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Sudan's top army general, Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, appointed himself to head the new ruling body.

item.title: Saudi Court Blocks Execution of Man Convicted of Crime Committed at 14
item.description: Rights groups said the death sentence for Abdullah al-Huwaiti ran contrary to the kingdom’s claimed legal reforms. Now he’ll be retried.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Asmaa al-Omar

item.title: Outside COP26, Trash in Glasgow Piles High
item.description: At COP26, delegates address the need to curb emissions and mass consumption to save the planet while the reality of today’s throwaway society is all too apparent nearby.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trash piled up this week in Glasgow’s streets in Finnieston, an area near the COP26 summit.

item.title: India's Stock Market is Soaring, Luring Investors at Home and Abroad
item.description: The second-most populous country is enjoying some of the world’s strongest stock market returns. Pro-growth policies and gnawing questions about China have helped.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: The parent company of the digital payments platform Paytm went public this week in the largest offering in India’s history.

item.title: China and the United States Join in Seeking Emissions Cuts
item.description: As nearly 200 nations struggle over global climate negotiations, the world’s two biggest polluters sign an agreement, but it was short on details.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: China's climate envoy, Xie Zhenhua, in Glasgow on Wednesday. “There is more agreement between China and the U.S. than divergence,” he said.

item.title: Europe, Taiwan Inch Closer as Distrust of Beijing Grows
item.description: Talks between European lawmakers and Taiwanese officials point to Europe’s increasing willingness to strengthen relations, despite Beijing’s threats.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Joseph Wu, Taiwan’s foreign minister, speaking during a visit to Prague last month.

item.title: Boris Johnson Handles Scandal Amid Climate Conference
item.description: As the host leader of the U.N. conference on global warming, Mr. Johnson was hoping to project statesmanship. But a mushrooming ethics scandal dominated the week, overshadowing his climate ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, center, attended the United Nations’ climate conference in Glasgow on Wednesday.

item.title: Harris Meets Macron, Signaling a ‘New Era’ After Sub Snub, Both Say
item.description: In her vague assignment abroad, the vice president seems to be emphasizing that the U.S.-France relationship is about looking forward, in the wake of an embarrassing diplomatic spat.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France greeting Vice President Kamala Harris at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: French Court Convicts Man in the Murder of a Holocaust Survivor
item.description: The man, Yacine Mihoub, was sentenced to life imprisonment for killing Mireille Knoll, 85, in 2018, which judges said was a hate crime motivated by the fact that she was Jewish.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Flowers and placards outside Mireille Knoll’s apartment in Paris in 2018. Her partly burned body was found in March 2018; she had been stabbed 11 times.

item.title: Veterans Have Become Unlikely Lobbyists in Push to Legalize Psychedelic Drugs
item.description: Lawmakers find it hard to “just say no” to combat veterans seeking support for drug decriminalization efforts gaining traction around the country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Damon Casarez for The New York Times

item.title: Austria Weighs a Lockdown for Unvaccinated People
item.description: The country’s case rate has more than doubled since late October.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: New Covid-19 cases have been surging in Austria recently. Cars lined up last week at a drive-through coronavirus testing station in Innsbruck.

item.title: On the Ground: Migrants in Poland's Forests Are Hiding and Hurting
item.description: The forests stretch past a restricted zone, and it is there that migrants like this group of eight who have made it past the guards and the razor wire are waiting for an opportunity to continue on.
item.dc:creator: Maciek Nabrdalik and Marc Santora
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: As Poland Celebrates Its Independence Day, Far-Right Groups Stage Rallies
item.description: In downtown Warsaw, tens of thousands of demonstrators started their march by lighting red flares and singing the national anthem.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Members of far-right groups marched in Warsaw on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Reacts to Belarus-Poland Border Crisis
item.description: President Vladimir Putin’s spokesman said that Russia was doing all it could to resolve the situation, but he also warned of the possibility of a military escalation, according to the Russian state news agency RIA Novosti.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in Moscow in September.

item.title: Europe's Covid Deaths Rose 10 Percent in a Week, the W.H.O. Says
item.description: Cases and fatalities have increased on the continent, even as they have dropped or remained stable in other parts of the globe.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: An emergency unit at a hospital in Bucharest, Romania, this month.

item.title: Why Modern Medicine Struggles With Treating Chronic Pain
item.description: And what comes next?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

item.title: Dropouts and Menial Jobs: The Effects of Keeping Uganda's Schools Closed
item.description: With 10 million young people in Uganda still unable to attend classes in person, the impact for many has been devastating.
item.dc:creator: Musinguzi Blanshe
item.media:description: Lining up for inspection in March before final examinations at Mbogo Mixed Secondary School, Wakiso, Uganda.

item.title: Tracing Mexico’s Complicated Relationship With Rice
item.description: Having arrived in the country via the Spanish Conquest, the grain’s presence poses the question: What’s native, and what isn’t, when it comes to a nation’s culinary history?
item.dc:creator: Aatish Taseer and Stefan Ruiz

item.title: For Many Members of the Arab American Diaspora, Mansaf Offers a Taste of Home
item.description: The traditional Bedouin dish of bread, rice, lamb and yogurt is a talisman of identity in Jordan — and in various communities in suburban Detroit.
item.dc:creator: Diana Abu-Jaber and Renee Cox

item.title: In Senegal, a Return to Homegrown Rice
item.description: The country has remained mostly dependent on the grain’s importation since colonization in the 1800s. But some locals are trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: Angela Flournoy and Manuel Obadia-Wills

item.title: The Thrilling Dare of Scorched Rice
item.description: When browned on the bottom of the pot by a skilled cook, the grain is transformed into a complex delicacy, one prized by food cultures around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and Anthony Cotsifas

item.title: China's Xi Jingping Secures Political Future By Rewriting Past
item.description: Senior party officials have gathered at a closed-door meeting in Beijing to cement Mr. Xi’s dominance as he moves to claim a likely third term next year as China’s leader.
item.media:description: Communist Party officials are expected to decide this week whether Xi Jinping, left, will be placed among the country’s era-defining leaders.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Crisis at the E.U. border.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Migrants from the Middle East and elsewhere at the Belarus-Poland border.

item.title: Bolsonaro Joins a Centrist Party in Brazil Ahead of 2022 Re-election Bid
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro, who has not belonged to any political party for two years, is joining the centrist Liberals, they said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has reached a deal with the centrist Liberal Party to back his re-election bid, according to a party statement.

item.title: Blinken Warns Russia Against Making a ‘Serious Mistake’ in Ukraine
item.description: Appearing with Ukraine’s foreign minister, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the intentions behind Moscow’s latest military buildup were unclear.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken this week. He met with Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, on Wednesday amid reports of new Russian military deployments near its border with Ukraine.

item.title: Migrants Say They Face Abuse on Both Sides of Belarus Border
item.description: Stories are emerging of the authorities in Belarus, Lithuania and Poland abusing asylum seekers from the Middle East and using them as political pawns.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reben Sirwan, 29, in Sulaimani, Iraq, after being deported from Belarus this week.

item.title: Israeli Experts Approve Vaccinations for Children Ages 5 to 11
item.description: Israel would become one of the first countries after the United States to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children ages 5 to 11.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Shamir
item.media:description: Returning to school in Tel Aviv in September. On Wednesday Israeli experts approved vaccines for children ages 5 to 11. The remaining hurdle is Health Ministry approval.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Migrants flood Poland-Belarus border.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Members of a Kurdish family from Iraq waiting for the border guard patrol in a forest on the Polish side of the border with Belarus on Tuesday.

item.title: Pennsylvania Court Rejects Statewide School Mask Mandate
item.description: The judges said that the state’s acting health secretary had overstepped her authority in issuing the mandate, and that they were not taking a position on “the science or efficacy of mask-wearing.”
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Andrew Rush/Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Students catching a bus in September in Ambridge, Pa.

item.title: Manuel Chang Will Face Corruption Charges in U.S.
item.description: A judge overturned the South African government’s decision to send the minister back to Mozambique, where civil society groups say his political clout will protect him.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Manuel Chang, Mozambique's former finance minister, at an extradition hearing in Johannesburg in 2019.

item.title: Boris Johnson Urges Negotiators to Break Impasse in Final Climate Summit Hours
item.description: “Now is the time to get together and show the determination needed to power on through the blockages,” the British prime minister said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Wednesday at the COP26 climate change conference.

item.title: Greta Thunberg, Activists Petition U.N. to Declare State of Emergency on Climate Change
item.description: Young climate activists on Wednesday called on the U.N. to declare a “Level 3” emergency, as it did for Covid-19, allowing the institution to deploy resources to vulnerable countries.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg at a Fridays for Future rally in Glasgow last week.

item.title: In video: Razor wire, soldiers and desperation at the border.
Video of Salt Bae Serving Communist Leader Gold Steak Prompts Anger in Vietnam
item.description: A celebrity chef showed the meal in a TikTok video, now removed, that angered people in Vietnam. Facebook said it was investigating why the chef’s hashtag was blocked from its site.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Nusr-Et Steakhouse, a London-based restaurant of the social media star known as Salt Bae.

item.title: Little Amal, a Refugee Puppet, Looks for Home
item.description: In “The Walk,” a 12-foot tall, 9-year-old Syrian girl named Amal trekked from Turkey to Britain to find her mother. In a politically divided continent, were any minds changed?
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall, Carlotta Gall and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Puppeteers operating the 12-foot-tall Amal, a 9-year-old Syrian refugee on a journey to find her mother, in “The Walk.”

item.title: Pete Buttigieg Says U.S. 'Focused' on Reducing Auto Emissions
item.description: At the Glasgow climate summit, Mr. Buttigieg said the conversation surrounding climate change should focus on whether Earth can sustain life.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg speaking at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow, on Tuesday.

item.title: Germany Weighs New Covid Rules as Infections Reach Record Heights
item.description: Nearly 40,000 new cases were registered in the country on Tuesday — the third time a daily record was set within a week. “We have a real emergency situation,” a top virologist said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Treating Covid-19 patients at a hospital in Leipzig, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: American Journalist Held in Myanmar Faces 2 New Charges
item.description: Prosecutors filed charges of terrorism and sedition against the journalist Danny Fenster, who once worked at a hard-hitting news outlet hated by Myanmar’s governing military.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Fenster Family, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An undated photograph of the American journalist Danny Fenster. Myanmar prosecutors have filed two new charges against him: terrorism and sedition.

item.title: Why the Infrastructure Bill Matters
item.description: Will it show that government can still do big things?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: A commuter train in New Jersey.

item.title: This Chinese City Requires 28 Days of Quarantine. Then Another 28.
item.description: The restrictions in Shenyang are a stark example of how seriously officials are taking the country’s “zero Covid” approach to the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: An airport in Shenyang, China, which has imposed some of the strictest Covid requirements for foreign visitors: extensive testing, 28 days in a hotel and another 28 days at home.

item.title: The Joy of Fly Fishing in Italy
item.description: Italy is not often mentioned as a fly fishing destination, but the wonder of Italian alpine fishing is now making itself known.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth R. Rosen
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angelo Piller, a fly fishing guide, casting in the Misurina Lake in the Veneto region of the Dolomites, Italy.

item.title: In France, the People COP26 Forgot Seethe Over Rising Energy Prices
item.description: In one area of France, worries about rising energy prices trump anxiety about rising temperatures, raising fears of a resurgence of the Yellow Vest social uprising.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner protesting a methane-producing recycling plant on the field where it is planned to be built on the outskirts of Montargis, France.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Troops at the Poland-Belarus border.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Hundreds of people camped at the Belarus-Poland border in frigid weather seeking to enter Poland.

item.title: U.S. Holocaust Museum Says China ‘May Be Committing Genocide’ Against Uyghurs
item.description: Its report found that the government’s attacks against the group of Muslims in Xinjiang had escalated and most likely included “forced sterilization, sexual violence, enslavement, torture, and forcible transfer.”
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Simon-Skjodt Center for the Prevention of Genocide
item.media:description: Members of a Uyghur family prayed at the grave of a loved one at a cemetery in Xinjiang in 2016.

item.title: Malala Yousafzai Announces Her Marriage
item.description: Ms. Yousafzai, a Pakistani activist and the youngest-ever recipient of a Nobel Peace Prize, married her partner at a small ceremony in Birmingham, England, she said on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Malala Yousafzai and her husband, Asser Malik.

item.title: Afghan Pilots Who Escaped Taliban Are Flown Out of Tajikistan
item.description: More than 140 Afghan Air Force pilots and crew members were evacuated to the United Arab Emirates three months after flying into Tajikistan to escape the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan Air Force ground crew members servicing a military plane in Kabul in 2018.

item.title: Pakistan Reaches Cease-Fire With Resurgent Taliban Militants
item.description: The Pakistani government said it would offer amnesty for insurgents who are willing to disarm.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: A military outpost in Khyber District, Pakistan, in August.

item.title: Ethiopia Seizes 16 UN Workers Amid Efforts to Halt Tigray War
item.description: The detentions aggravated the already tense relations between the United Nations and the Ethiopian government over war and hunger in the country’s rebel-held Tigray region.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A military parade in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: India’s Covid turnaround has blind spots.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A healthcare worker administers a dose of the coronavirus vaccine in Ahmedabad, India, in June.

item.title: France Will Require Booster Shot for Those 65 and Older
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, in a televised speech, said that older people will now have to get the shots to remain eligible for a vaccine passport.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron last month in Paris.

item.title: Canada Approves Pfizer Boosters for Adults
item.description: Some provinces have already started to offer booster shots to higher-risk populations. Tuesday’s announcement standardizes eligibility criteria nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A health care worker administers the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at a pop-up clinic in Toronto this year.

item.title: Macron announces a new vaccine rule for people 65 or older in France.
item.description: Though the country has a high vaccination rate, new coronavirus cases and hospital admissions have been increasing in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Red Cross volunteers helping a man activate his pass on the TousAntiCovid contact-tracing application in Le Bourget, France.
